hints.content: Start by converting the number `num` into a string. This will allow you to easily extract substrings of length `k`. Remember that substrings are contiguous sequences of characters.

Think about how to generate all possible substrings of length `k`. You can use a loop that goes from the start of the string to the end, making sure to only consider indices that allow for a full substring of length `k`.

When you extract a substring, convert it back to an integer. Be cautious with substrings that may represent numbers with leading zeros, as they are valid but will affect how you check for divisibility.
Remember that `0` is not a valid divisor. If a substring evaluates to `0`, you should skip it when counting the k-beauty.
For each valid substring, check if it is a divisor of `num`. You can do this by using the modulo operator: if `num % substring == 0`, then it is a divisor.
Keep a counter to track how many valid substrings meet the conditions for being a divisor of `num`. Initialize this counter to zero and increment it whenever you find a valid substring.
Consider edge cases such as when `k` is equal to the length of `num`. In this case, you will only have one substring to check, which is the number itself.
Make sure to handle large numbers correctly. Since `num` can be as large as 10^9, ensure that your approach can handle the maximum constraints without performance issues.
After checking all possible substrings, return the count of valid divisors you found. This will be your final answer for the k-beauty of the number.
As a final step, remember to test your solution with different inputs, including edge cases like leading zeros and the maximum value of `num`.

questionNotes: 1 <= k <= num.length (taking num as a string)
Leading zeros are allowed in substrings.
0 is not a divisor of any number.
